headline: Perfect Potato Soup
description: This thick and chunky potato soup with crispy bacon, carrots, celery, and onion is a satisfying family-friendly dinner that's easy to make.

video.name: How to Make Perfect Potato Soup

name: Perfect Potato Soup
recipeIngredient: 6 russet potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch cubes
1.5 teaspoons freshly ground black pepper, divided

recipeInstructions.text: Place potatoes into a large pot and cover with water; bring to a boil. Cook until fork-tender, about 10 minutes. Drain.
Place bacon in a large saucepan and cook over medium-high heat, turning occasionally, until crispy, about 8 minutes. Drain bacon slices on paper towels. Pour out bacon grease.

Melt butter in the saucepan over medium heat, scraping the bottom of the pan with a flat-edged wooden spoon. Add celery, onion, carrots, 1 teaspoon salt, and 1/2 teaspoon pepper; cook and stir until tender, about 10 minutes. Sprinkle in flour; cook and stir for 2 minutes.

Pour half-and-half and chicken broth into the saucepan. Add potatoes, 1 teaspoon salt, 1/2 teaspoon pepper, thyme, cayenne pepper, and nutmeg. Bring to a boil, stirring frequently. Stir in bacon pieces. Reduce heat and simmer, stirring often, until flavors combine, about 10 minutes.
Ladle into serving bowls. Garnish with 1/2 teaspoon pepper, green onions, and paprika.

review.reviewBody: I made this soup for friends on a Saturday came home and made it again Sunday. People were moaning it was so good.
I love this soup. I put cheese on top when serving. Great flavor.
Wonderful recipe! I am wondering if I can freeze the leftover?
Delicious!

I stuck to this recipe almost to the letter and it was truly perfect. The only thing I changed was whizzing it a bit with an immersion blender to puree some of the soup. I left it chunky though. If you go this route, the pureed potatoes will thicken the soup as well. I thinned it with a little half and half and it was perfect again. If you want to load it up, you can definitely add, shredded cheddar, bacon bits, scallions and/or sour cream when serving, or have it available for picky eaters to add if they want, but the soup doesn't need it.
I followed this recipe. Did not care for this soup.

Easy recipe. Of course had to adjust seasonings to my taste…more salt/cayenne/nutmeg 
What I did at the end was blend the soup with my nutribullet. I think doing this even brought out more flavor. 
I’d make this again.
OMG! This soup is absolutely delicious. The perfect winter soup. I used smoked paprika because I ran out the plain paprika. Easy to make. It will not disappoint.

Made this twice, easy, delicious, family loves it..like eating a loaded baked potato topped with a bit of shred cheese and scallions. It doesnt say what size potatoes to use so you may have to adjust amount of half n half and broth to achieve desired consistency, definitely if using larger potatoes.. or maybe use 1 less. Also I use 6 thicker cut bacon and sweet yellow onion. Best served in 
lil sourdough rounds!

GREAT TASTE!!
I subbed shallots for Onion.
Used extra bacon because....BACON!
No nutmeg.
Milk for half n half.
And "Better than Bouillon" for my stock.
Sooooo good!!!
It thickens up nicely...we put it in bread bowls for a rainy December lunch.

5 stars all the way! Easy to make! Didn't change a thing. It was fantabulous!
A keeper for sure.

This soup came out with more of a consistency of a stew, but it did not hurt the flavor or hardiness of the meal. We added bratwurst to the pot just for some added protein. This will definitely be one recipe we repeat. The only thing we will do differently however is to cut the Celery into smaller pieces.
No changes, awesome as is.
We made several mistakes in making this soup and it was still fantastic. We added corn and that made it even better.

First of all, this is far from a perfect potato soup. But it is recoverable. Following the recipe, I ended up with bland wallpaper paste with a few chunks in it. But I really can't afford to throw out a whole pot of soup. So I stuck it in the fridge overnight and thought about what I could do to fix it. After some research, it appeared I could recover it with more chicken broth and maybe I could cure the blandness with a few herbs and a bit more salt and pepper. It worked and became a pretty good potato soup. But I added enough broth to double the amount in the recipe. Not a keeper for me.

This soup is "perfect"!!! I used milk instead of half and half just to lower the calories. So good! The spice mix was great but I want to add a bit of garlic next time as someone else recommended . Thanks so much for this recipe.
This soup is so good and a real tummy warmer, comfort food. Easy recipe when you use the micro wave to pre-cook carrots and potatoes. Add a French bread, and a salad.
I didn't have bacon so I used chicken. Turned out great. Also added granulated garlic.

Turned out great but I added a little more chicken stock to keep it from being way too thick and I suggest a couple more celery sticks. I did let it simmer for about 15 min which helped soften the potatoes since I was being careful not to overcook them early on. I did add about a 1/2 cup of sour cream which really gave it that extra kick ! I put it in containers to let it cool which kept the potatoes from getting too mushy as they seem to keep cooking. Topped with crispy bacon, cheese, a dollop of sour cream and sprinkled scallions ! Mmm it was good !
No nutmeg
Easy to follow! I added a little milk toward the end to thin it out a little, but it is amazingly delicious!!
This soup is great. I added more bacon that called for, cause I am a bacon lover. I omitted the cayanne pepper, don't like it. The soup turned out great and I highly reccommend it.

This is a great basic recipe. I added additional chicken broth and milk to thin it as I added some corn and red bell pepper and it was too thick. I also only had a pint of cream. I adjusted spices to my taste. 
I have made variations of this a few times now. Today I used the potato water, chicken broth and less than a pint of cream. With the roux to thicken, I don’t feel the need to use as much cream. I don’t drink milk so none on hand. I also use the bacon grease to sauté the veg instead of tossing it, and 4 leeks instead of onion. These spices are good, use the nutmeg! I like about a teaspoon and a half red pepper, 2 tsp smoked paprika. Fresh thyme is better than dried in this, but today I used dried. I reserve the bacon for garnish, and add grated cheddar, green onion, and sour cream or yogurt. It’s a good backbone recipe. Feel free to add whatever you need to use up!
I doubled the recipe...it’s excellent and easy.
This recipe was delicious! The only change I made was I left out the nutmeg because I am not a fan of it. This recipe is definitely a keeper. Thanks for sharing

This recipe is awesome. My main difference was to make the soup in the potato pot (instead of the veggie saucepan) with just a little bit of the starchy potato water to help the soup base. For the base, this was another change: I used about 3 parts chicken broth to 2 parts half and half (with a splash of whole milk to perfect the consistency since I used a whole lot of dying veggies), which I think comes close to flipping the recipe ratios. That was mainly to be calorie conscious but also because I didn’t have enough half and half! This one turned out great but I’m sure you can do the base however you want.

Delicious!! couple of changes--added more stock than the recipe called for. I found it rather "thick". It was plenty thick enough with the added stock. I also eliminated the bacon only because my husband does care for bacon! I'll make this again.

It's not often that I stick to the recipe as written. In this case, I substituted one of the Russet potatoes for a sweet potato. I only peeled about half of each potato. That way it gave the soup the added bonus of bits of potato skins. The potatoes we had might have been rather large, because it was turning out to be too thick (IMO). I added another 1/2 cup of chicken broth and 1/2 cup of half and half to thin it out. Even with the extra cup of liquid it was still thicker than most potato soups. Since we were eating the soup immediately after cooking, I wanted the flavors to blend faster, so for about half of the amount of thyme the recipe called for I used ground rather than dried flakes.

Other than that, I probably used around 20% less salt than the recipe called for and unfortunately I didn't have any green onion.

The end result was very tasty. My wife liked it and said that it reminded her of chicken pot pie. Ah HA! At least with how I made it, that is basically what it tastes like. Except for being without chicken meat, it tastes a lot like the chicken pot pies from KFC. The next time I make it I'm thinking that I should search for a flaky crust recipe and use this (modified) recipe to make vegetarian pot pies.
It was delicious. Substituted milk for half and half, shallots for onions and added a clove of garlic. Changes were thanks to another review for this recipe. Thanks.
This recipe was amazing!!! One of my favorite recipes!!!
My husband made this today and it was the best potato soup I’ve ever had! Followed the recipe and it truly was perfect!
We enjoyed it, I added some sour cream to it and used dill in it. Had a nice flavor to it.
Absolute Yum! I usually like cheesy potato soups, but I had a friend coming over who can’t have cheese. So glad I tried this! One of our new favorites! (FYI I didn’t add the cayenne pepper or nutmeg)
I like to follow the recipe as is the first time, then maybe play around with it later. This one is a keeper. If I never did anything else to it, we would enjoy it every time.
Our favorite potato soup

We loved this. The combination of flavors was perfect. Seconds were had by all and we will gladly be eating the leftovers this week. My changes were adding 3 cloves of minced garlic along with the sautéed veggies, 3 extra cups of chicken broth because there wasn't enough liquid for my potatoes, using fresh instead of dried thyme, and omitting the cayenne. I will definitely make again and probably use milk instead of half and half as I don't think the great taste would be compromised and maybe add some shallots as well. Thanks for a great new soup recipe!

10.2.16 Starting to think of Fall (I can dream, even though it’s still in the 90’s in Florida) and even more of soup. This is a very nice potato soup, but I would recommend if you’re “spice-sensitive,” start with a little less cayenne, and then add more to suit your taste. We’re about middle-of-the-road on spiciness, and this just was just a tad too much cayenne for us (personal taste). I used fat-free half-and-half to lighten the soup, and didn’t feel there was any sacrifice in flavor, otherwise, followed the recipe to the letter. The texture slightly thickened (perfectly), there was just a tiny bit of a crunch from the carrots and the celery (just the way we like it), and I did set aside some of the bacon for a garnish. The recipe indicates preparation time is 1 hour and 20 minutes, but this will be on the table in about 35-40 minutes. Marilee Wilson Mack, thanks for a really tasty new soup!
